questions.question: When tracking experiments and model lineage across teams, which combination provides end-to-end provenance and reproducibility?
questions.answer: Vertex AI Metadata combined with Data Catalog provides end-to-end provenance and reproducibility for experiment tracking and model lineage across teams by automatically capturing runs, artifacts, and data asset relationships in a unified metadata system.
questions.explanation:
## Correct Answer
Vertex AI Metadata provides structured tracking of runs and artifacts, and Data Catalog offers centralized data asset provenance; together they enable end-to-end lineage and reproducibility.

## Why Other Options Are Wrong
- b: Logs alone do not capture model artifacts or experimental lineage.
- c: Manual tracing is error-prone and not scalable.
- d: Cloud Trace focuses on distributed tracing of API calls, not ML asset lineage.

## Key Concepts
- Vertex AI Metadata (ML Metadata)
- Data Catalog

## Real-World Application
- Ensures researchers and engineers can reproduce experiments across teams with auditable lineage.

questions.question: Design a multi-tenant, privacy-preserving online inference and feature materialization pipeline on GCP for a cross-region ride-hailing platform. Each tenant has its own feature schema and data residency needs. Outline how you would manage per-tenant Feature Store namespaces, Canary deployments across tenants, live vs. batch feature materialization, drift/bias monitoring, provenance, and automated rollback with Vertex AI Endpoints, Dataflow, and Pub/Sub. Include concrete rollback criteria and cost considerations?
questions.answer: Use per-tenant feature store namespaces and a tenant-scoped Vertex AI Endpoint. Ingest events with Pub/Sub, materialize online features in Dataflow into a tenant-specific online store, and route reque
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked

Explores multi-tenant data isolation, per-tenant schemas, data residency, and governance in production ML pipelines, plus practical rollback and cost controls.

## Key Concepts

- Multi-tenant Feature Store namespaces and tenant-scoped endpoints
- Data residency controls (EU/US), VPC Service Controls, RBAC
- Canary rollouts per tenant with traffic-splitting
- Drift and bias monitoring across tenants; data provenance
- Online/Offline feature materialization via Dataflow; Pub/Sub as ingestion backbone

## Code Example

```yaml
tenants:
  - id: tenant-A
    feature_store: projects/xxx/locations/us-central1/featurestores/tenantA
    endpoint: https://endpointA.example.com/predict
  - id: tenant-B
    feature_store: projects/xxx/locations/eu-west1/featurestores/tenantB
    endpoint: https://endpointB.example.com/predict
```

## Follow-up Questions

- How would you detect data poisoning or schema drift in real time across tenants?
- What rollback criteria would you enforce for drift, latency, or cost violations, and how would you automate it across regions?
questions.diagram:
flowchart TD
A[Event with TenantID] --> B[Feature Store (per-tenant namespace)]
B --> C[Materialize Online Features]
C --> D[Vertex AI Endpoint (tenant-scoped)]
D --> E[Canary Controller]
E --> F[Monitoring & Drift Detection]

questions.question: Design a beginner-friendly end-to-end GCP pipeline for a price-optimization model. Use Vertex AI for training and hosting, Vertex AI Feature Store for online/offline features, Dataflow for ETL into BigQuery, and Pub/Sub for ingestion. Describe data flow, feature derivation cadence, training trigger cadence, online/offline feature consistency, and a simple rollback strategy if offline metrics degrade. Include a basic cost plan?
questions.answer: Dataflow ingests price and demand signals into BigQuery; derive features like price elasticity and seasonality; feed online features to Vertex AI Feature Store. Train nightly with Vertex AI, deploy to
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked
Tests ability to design a practical, beginner-friendly GCP ML pipeline across multiple services, focusing on data flow, feature management, and simple rollback. 

## Key Concepts
- Vertex AI training and hosting
- Vertex AI Feature Store (online/offline features)
- Dataflow for ETL into BigQuery
- Pub/Sub ingestion for streaming signals
- Training triggers, drift checks, and rollback strategy

## Code Example
```javascript
// Lightweight drift check example (pseudo)
function driftScore(current, baseline) {
  const diff = Math.abs(current - baseline);
  return diff / Math.max(1, baseline);
}
```

## Follow-up Questions
- How would you validate consistency between online and offline features?
- Which metrics signal a rollback, and how would you automate it?

  Dataflow --> BigQuery[BigQuery]
  BigQuery --> FeatureStore[Vertex AI Feature Store]
  FeatureStore --> OnlineServing[Online Serving]
  Dataflow --> Training[Vertex AI Training]
  Training --> Serving[Vertex AI Endpoint]

questions.question: You operate a multi-tenant content recommender service on GCP used by advertisers. Each tenant has its own feature schema and data retention. Design a production ML pipeline (training and online serving) using Vertex AI, Feature Store, Pub/Sub, and Dataflow that supports **per-tenant namespaces**, **policy-based access**, **drift monitoring**, **automated rollback**, and **cost isolation**. Include data leakage prevention, schema evolution, and canary rollouts across regions?
questions.answer: Use tenant-scoped Feature Stores and separate training runs per tenant via Vertex AI Pipelines. Route streaming data through Pub/Sub and Dataflow into per-tenant online/offline stores, with IAM per-te
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked
This question probes how candidates architect multi-tenant ML workflows with governance, isolation, and reliability. It emphasizes production concerns beyond single-tenant pipelines.

## Key Concepts
- Multi-tenant feature store namespaces
- IAM and per-tenant isolation
- Drift detection and monitoring per tenant
- Canary rollouts and automated rollbacks
- Cost isolation via quotas and budgets
- Schema evolution and data leakage prevention
- Cross-region delivery and auditability

## Code Example
```javascript
function featureStorePath(tenantId, project, location = 'us-central1') {
  return `projects/${project}/locations/${location}/featurestores/${tenantId}_fs`;
}
```

## Follow-up Questions
- How would you validate cross-tenant feature leakage guarantees? 
- How would you implement tenant-specific canary traffic and rollbacks at scale?

questions.question: Design a real-time content moderation inference path on GCP that adds a Redis-based in‑memory cache in front of a Vertex AI online endpoint to reduce latency and cost. Outline what you cache (embeddings vs predictions), key schema (e.g., user_id, model_version, language), TTL and eviction policy, and how you invalidate cache on model deploy or feature updates. Include data privacy considerations and a plan for monitoring latency, cache hit rate, and drift. Provide a small Python sketch of the cache lookup?
questions.answer: Add a Redis cache in front of the Vertex AI online endpoint. Cache embeddings or prediction results keyed by user_id, model_version, language. Use a short TTL (5–15 min) with invalidation on new deplo
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked

Tests practical cache design between online model serving, latency, and cost, plus how to keep data private and fresh.

## Key Concepts

- In‑memory caching in front of online endpoints
- Cache keys tied to user_id, language, and model_version
- Invalidation triggers on model deploys or feature updates
- Data privacy: hashing identifiers before caching
- Observability: latency, cache hit rate, drift checks

## Code Example

```python
import redis
import hashlib

cache = redis.Redis(host='redis-host', port=6379)

def cache_key(user_id, model_version, language):
    return f"{hashlib.sha256(user_id.encode()).hexdigest()}:{model_version}:{language}"

def get_inference(user_id, model_version, language, compute_embedding, ttl=900):
    key = cache_key(user_id, model_version, language)
    val = cache.get(key)
    if val is not None:
        return val
    value = compute_embedding(user_id)
    cache.setex(key, ttl, value)
    return value
```

## Follow-up Questions

- How would you validate cache correctness when model_version changes?
- How would you scale Redis for bursty traffic while preventing stale data?
questions.diagram:
flowchart TD
  Client[Client] --> Cache[Redis Cache]
  Cache --> Endpoint[Vertex AI Endpoint]
  Endpoint --> Cache
  Cache --> FeatureStore[Feature Store]

questions.question: Design a multi-tenant ML service on GCP that serves diverse customers with strict data isolation and retention policies. Propose a deployment and feature governance pattern using Vertex AI, Feature Store, Private Service Connect, Data Catalog, and Pub/Sub to isolate customer data, manage per-tenant feature lifecycles, perform drift monitoring, and enable tenant-specific canary rollouts with automated rollback and cost controls. Include concrete components, data flow, and rollback criteria?
questions.answer: Use a per-tenant project and separate datasets; expose a single endpoint with traffic-split by tenant via Vertex AI Endpoints with canary deployments per tenant. Store features per-tenant in Feature S
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked

Tests ability to design a scalable, compliant ML service with strict data isolation across tenants, a common real-world constraint.

## Key Concepts

- Multi-tenant data isolation and policy enforcement
- Vertex AI Endpoints and canary deployments per tenant
- Feature Store per-tenant featureviews and telemetry via Pub/Sub
- Model Monitoring, drift-driven rollback, and cost controls

## Code Example

```python
# Pseudo-code: create canary deployment per tenant (illustrative)
from google.cloud import aiplatform
endpoint = aiplatform.Endpoint(".../endpoints/...")
endpoint.deploy_model(
  display_name="tenant-a-canary",
  model_id="projects/.../models/...",
  dedicated_resources=None,
  traffic_split={"0": 0.2, "1": 0.8},
)
```

## Follow-up Questions

- How would you design alerting thresholds for drift vs latency?
- How would you test tenant-specific policy changes before rollout?
questions.diagram:
flowchart TD
  TenantIsolation[Tenant Isolation] --> Endpoint[Vertex AI Endpoint per Tenant]
  Endpoint --> Canary[Canary Deploy per Tenant]
  Canary --> Telemetry[Telemetry via Pub/Sub]
  Telemetry --> Dataflow[Feature Ingestion & Materialization]
  Endpoint --> Drift[Model Monitoring]
  Drift --> Rollback[Auto Rollback on Drift/Latency]
  Policy[Policy & Retention via Data Catalog/IAM] --> DataStore[Storage & Cost Controls]
